subject: Languages
title: Double Negatives: Not Always Wrong
description: One-minute skill: Double Negatives: Not Always Wrong.

hook.text: 'I don't know nothing' is wrong in standard English. In Spanish, French, and Old English, it's perfectly correct.

buildup.text: Double negatives (negative concord) were standard in English until the 18th century.

discovery.text: Chaucer wrote 'He nevere yet no vileynye ne sayde' â€” a quadruple negative meaning 'He never said anything rude.'

twist.text: Grammarians decided double negatives were 'illogical' â€” borrowing rules from math, not language.

climax.text: Today, double negatives are stigmatized in English but perfectly standard in most world languages.

punchline.text: Double negatives aren't bad grammar. They're good grammar that lost a political battle.

quiz.question: Why are double negatives considered wrong in modern standard English?
options: They were always wrong in English
